messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using JavaScript and the Express.js framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `routes/productRoutes.js`, I found that `productRoutes` is implemented to process HTTP requests. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
Summary — base prefix
- productRoutes is mounted in server.js with app.use('/api/products', productRoutes). All route paths in routes/productRoutes.js are therefore prefixed with /api/products.

Endpoints discovered (full paths and method allowances)

1) Path: /api/products
- all (ANY): false
- HEAD: false
- POST: true
- OPTIONS: false
- TRACE: false
- GET: true
- PUT: false
- DELETE: false
- PATCH: false

2) Path: /api/products/{id}/reviews
- all (ANY): false
- HEAD: false
- POST: true
- OPTIONS: false
- TRACE: false
- GET: false
- PUT: false
- DELETE: false
- PATCH: false

3) Path: /api/products/top
- all (ANY): false
- HEAD: false
- POST: false
- OPTIONS: false
- TRACE: false
- GET: true
- PUT: false
- DELETE: false
- PATCH: false

4) Path: /api/products/{id}
- all (ANY): false
- HEAD: false
- POST: false
- OPTIONS: false
- TRACE: false
- GET: true
- PUT: true
- DELETE: true
- PATCH: false

Explanation / reasoning
- server.js mounts productRoutes at the prefix '/api/products' (app.use('/api/products', productRoutes)), so every router path is prefixed with /api/products.
- routes/productRoutes.js defines the following Express route registrations:
  - router.route('/').get(getProducts).post(protect, admin, createProduct) → maps to GET and POST on '/api/products'.
  - router.route('/:id/reviews').post(protect, checkObjectId, createProductReview) → maps to POST on '/api/products/{id}/reviews'.
  - router.get('/top', getTopProducts) → maps to GET on '/api/products/top'.
  - router.route('/:id').get(checkObjectId, getProductById).put(protect, admin, checkObjectId, updateProduct).delete(protect, admin, checkObjectId, deleteProduct) → maps to GET, PUT, DELETE on '/api/products/{id}'.
- No router.route(...).all(...) calls are present, so "all (ANY)" is false for each path.
- The HEAD, OPTIONS, TRACE methods are not explicitly registered in the code for any of these routes, so they are reported as false (per your instruction to base acceptance on the code, not on framework behaviors or assumptions).
- Middleware (protect, admin, checkObjectId) does not change which HTTP methods are registered — it only restricts access — so methods guarded by middleware are still reported as accepted by the route when present in the router registration.
- Path parameters in Express are defined with ':id' — converted here to the required OpenAPI-style {id} in the full path entries above.
